citeinfo.title: Within-stand spatial distribution of ponderosa pine mortality caused by the mountain pine beetle in the Colorado Front Range

descript.abstract: This data publication includes data collected in support of a study to examine the small scale, within stand, spatially-referenced ponderosa pine (Pinus ponderosa) tree mortality caused by the mountain pine beetle (Dendroctonus ponderosae) in a Colorado Front Range site. Data were collected in the summer of 1997 in an unmanaged low-elevation 3.1-hectare ponderosa pine stand in the Canyon Lakes Ranger District of the Arapaho-Roosevelt National Forest. Spatially referenced basal area points were measured with a 20 basal area factor (BAF) prism in a 10 meter (m) x 10 m grid. For all “in” trees we recorded tree species, diameter at breast height (1.4 m above the ground), and whether the tree was alive of killed by mountain pine beetle. No trees had died to other causes within the study area.
descript.purpose: Mountain pine beetle is a major natural disturbance agent that can cause extensive tree mortality of ponderosa pine in the Colorado Front Range and across western conifer forests in the United States. There is published information on the conditions that increase forest stand susceptibility to ponderosa pine, namely, dense stands with high host availability in the form of large-diameter trees. However, there is a paucity of data addressing the small scale, whiting stand variability in forest conditions that result in in the spatial distribution of tree mortality. This information can be useful for land managers when implementing forest restoration projects that aim to create similar pre-Euro-American settlement historical conditions. Restoration efforts aim primarily at reducing tree densities, increasing tree spacing and creating isolated clumps or large-diameter trees. These conditions could be suitable for the development of mountain pine beetle infestations when populations increase.

spdom.descgeog: This study was conducted in the Canyon Lakes Ranger District of the Arapaho-Roosevelt National Forest in Colorado. As the area was relatively small we provide only the coordinates for the centroid of the study site.

citeinfo.title: Within-stand distribution of tree mortality caused by the mountain pine beetle, Dendroctonus ponderosae Hopkins

attracc.attraccr:
Target tree species was ponderosa pine which is easily identifiable and comprised 99% of the trees sampled. Sample trees were those “in” trees as determined by a 20 basal area factor prism. Diameter at breast height was measured with a tree diameter tape at 1.4 meters (m) above the ground. These are standard forestry mensuration techniques that yield reliable measurements when properly used. Mountain pine beetle-killed trees are easily identifiable by signs of attack such as pitch tubes, boring dust in bark crevices and on the ground, and insect constructed galleries under the bark. These standard techniques and identification methods render data collection very reliable. The most common source of error is for the data recorder person to not hear the information correctly but this is mitigated by voicing the information back to the sampler. There is always the possibility if incorrect recording of information on the data sheets.
Prior to data processing, data were checked for accuracy by both the scientist and support staff.

dataqual.complete: We established sampling points in a 10 m x 10 m grid over the study area. All grid points were sampled.

method.methdesc:
STUDY DESIGN A 10 m x 10 m grid was superimposed over a 3.1-hectare (ha) area and at each grid point, a variable radius plot was established using a basal area factor prism that approximates 4.6 metric BAF (a basal area factor of 20 in U.S. customary units was used during data collection) to determine basal area at each point. For all plot trees, we recorded species, diameter at breast height (dbh), and tree condition as alive or MPB-killed; no trees appeared to have died due to other causes. Beetle-killed trees were confirmed by the presence of egg galleries under the bark. As plots were closely spaced, some trees could occur in adjacent plots but this common when collecting spatially-referenced data at small scales. Data were collected after the collapse of elevated mountain pine beetle populations of limited extent, which occurred in the early to mid-1990s. The study was conducted in a stand typical of low-elevation ponderosa pine in the Colorado Front Range and with a plant association commonly found in the Canyon Lakes Ranger District (Pinus ponderosa-Pseudotsuga menziesii/Muhlenbergia montana).
DATA MEASUREMENTS At each intersection point of the 10m x 10m grid, a basal area point was established with 20 Basal Area Factor prism (U.S. customary units). For all “in” trees in each plot the following data were recorded: tree species, dbh, and condition (live, mountain-pine beetle-killed, other dead). However, no other dead trees were observed.
See Negron (2020) for more details.

overview.eaover:
Below you will find a complete description of the files available in this data publication.
\Data\mpb_spatial_data.csv: Comma-delimited ASCII text file containing spatially-referenced ponderosa pine tree data from an unmanaged ponderosa pine stand exposed to an elevated mountain pine beetle population.
Variables include:
x_m = easting grid point location (meters)
x_y = northing grid point location (meters)
spp = tree species, where PP = ponderosa pine (Pinus ponderosae); BS = blue spruce (Picea pungens); JU = Rocky Mountain juniper (Juniperus scopulorum); DF = Douglas-fir (Pseudotsuga menziesii); LP = lodgepole pine (Pinus contorta); PF = limber pine (Pinus flexilis); QA = Gambel oak (Quercus gambelii); and X = no trees in point.
spp_code = code representing species, where 1 = BS; 2 = DF; 3 = JU; 4 = LP; 5 = PF; 6 = PP; 7 = QA; and 8 = X (species acronyms defined above in spp description)
Status_mpb = tree status, where 1 = live tree; 2 = mountain pine beetle-killed tree; -99 = no trees in point
dbh_cm = diameter at breast height (centimeters), where -99 = no trees in point
